hospitals.ldquoSinn Fein may have a list of demands about the Irish language which they need to satisfy a section of their support base, but I have a growing list of demands from all over the country from people who want to see progress in their schools, roads and hospitals.ldquoThose people are nationalists, republicans, unionists and those of no constitutional view.

title: former-workers-launch-legal-action-against-clinical-waste-firm-over-pay
story: Hundreds of workers were laid off after Healthcare Environmental Servicesceased trading in December.Thompsons solicitors said they are launching employment tribunal proceedings on behalf of more than  former staff, some of whom say they are owed up to five monthsrsquo pay.MSPs were told in January of a backlog of between  and  tonnes of clinical waste and  tonnes of anatomical waste at Scottish HES sites in Dundee and Shotts.HES has previously denied claims human body parts were among waste stockpiled at its sites but Environment Agency reports said the company stored remains of NHS patients in un-refrigerated units for more than six months.Thompsons partner David Martyn, who is in charge of the legal action, said: ldquoThe former employees of HES were dismissed without notice in December last year. They have now waited three months for their former employer to do the right thing and pay them the wages, notice pay and holiday pay they are owed.ldquoSome employees are owed up to five monthsrsquo pay and have had to resort to food banks to support their families. The time has now come for us to begin formal legal proceedings to force the company to pay the money the workers are due.HES became embroiled in a clinical waste stockpiling controversy with the NHS in , during which it denied claims human body parts were among items caught up in a backlog at its sites.On Thursday afternoon around  workers staged a protest outside the premises in Shotts calling for their wages to be paid.Greig Drysdale, who worked for HES for six months, said many of his former colleagues are owed thousands of pounds.He said: ldquoPeople are annoyed because thatrsquos three months without getting a wage. There are quite a few still not working although the majority have got jobs.ldquoI was only there for six months but Irsquom entitled to my wages, whether itrsquos six months or six years.Elizabeth Mellon, who worked at HES for  months, said she is owed around pound,.She said: ldquoI hope HES will see that wersquore still angry and upset.ldquoI started working again about five weeks ago and got paid but the wage just went to pay everyone back who had lent me money.Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard also attended the protest.He said: ldquoItrsquos a question of a fair dayrsquos pay for a fair dayrsquos work but itrsquos also a question of justice. The people that worked here who built this company up have been left abandoned with money owed to them and with lots of questions still unanswered.HES have been asked for a comment.The UK Government Insolvency Service said workerswho have had a contract for more than two years are entitled to redundancy pay.It said it has received  claims for redundancy and has paid out pound, to claimants, with only one claim outstanding.A spokesman said: ldquoHealthcare Environmental Services has not put itself into insolvency so under law the workers cannot claim for wages owed, notice pay or holiday pay at this time.ldquoIf the company puts itself into an insolvency procedure then these payments could be made.Sepa said it is carrying outregular inspections of the sites.A statement posted on the HES website in January said ldquothedirectors and senior managers of HES have fought daily for the survival of the business, while owner Garry Pettigrew said he was still fighting for workers.A Scottish Government spokesman said: ldquoWe have supported affected employees through our Pace initiative and will continue to monitor the situation and provide further support as required.ldquoThe company has claimed that their bank refused to release funds to pay salaries. Minister for Business, Fair Work and Skills Jamie Hepburn attempted to intervene in this situation and contacted Mr Pettigrew to seek his permission for the minister to contact the companyrsquos bank HSBC. Mr Pettigrew refused permission.ldquoIn response to a request from HES former employees, the minister then contacted HSBC directly, who advised they would require Mr Pettigrewrsquos permission to discuss any issues with the minister. Mr Pettigrew once again refused this permission.ldquoWe stand ready and willing to engage with them againthe company requires help in releasing funds to pay staff salaries.

title: mars-lander-starts-digging-on-red-planet
story: The German drilling instrument on the InSight lander struck what appeared to be a couple of stones.It only managed to burrow between half a footand about .ft , far short of the first digrsquos goal, said the German Aerospace Centre.The hammering device in the ldquomole was developed by the Astronika engineering company in Poland.How do you get to know someone deep down  Sometimes you have to dig a little bit ndash or in my case, burrow. Soon my robotic mole will start hammering itself into the ground, to help take the temperature of #Mars. Herersquos a look at how it works: pic nQdBxUiImdash NASA InSightFebruary , ldquoThis is not very good news for me because although the hammer is proving itselfhellip the Mars environment is not very favourable to us, said the companyrsquos chief engineer, Jerzy Grygorczuk.Over time, the team is shooting for a depth of up to ft , which would set an otherworldly record.The lander is digging deep to measure the planetrsquos internal temperature.InSight landed on Mars last November.Flight controllers at Nasarsquos Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Calornia sent commands to the lander on Thursday to begin digging.It will rest for a bit before burrowing again.The spacecraft already has a seismometer on the surface, listening for potential quakes.The lander is stationary, but has a robot arm to manoeuvre these two main experiments.

title: large-demonstrations-in-algeria-against-ailing-presidents-rule
story: It was an exceptional popular challenge to the countryrsquos secretive leadership.Protesters surged past a barricade and defied repeated volleys of tear gas fired by police in the march in Algiers.Most marchers were peaceful but a small group throwing stones clashed at the end of the event with police, causing some injuries.Such anti-government protests are unusual in Algeria, where questions are growing about Mr Bouteflikarsquos fitness for office after a  stroke that has left him largely hidden from public.Police helicopters circled overhead as crowds gathered in streets and parks of Algiers after midday Muslim prayer services to join the march.Organisers of the social media-driven movement hope the protest will send a loud signal of public discontent to Algeriarsquos secretive leadership before the April  presidential election.ldquoFor a free and democratic Algeria! shouted some demonstrators, or ldquoNo fth term!The crowd included families with small children and women in headscarves or jeans.Riot police lined key avenues, determined to keep marchers from nearing government buildings.Bursts of tear gas fire punctuated the afternoon, starting soon after crowds started gathering.More and more demonstrators joined in as the group marched along a route parallel to the cityrsquos Mediterranean shore.Police stopped the crowd near the central post office, and the protestersrsquo chants briefly fell silent as they joined together to sing the Algerian national anthem.Then the crowd overwhelmed a police barricade, pushing on toward Martyrsrsquo Square in the historic Casbah neighbourhood.

title: days-out-scotlands-15-most-unusual-museums
story: . Denny Ship Model Experiment Tank, DumbartonCastle Street, Dumbarton Open Monday-Saturday am-pmAdults pound., concessions pound, children freeWilliam Denny and Brothers turned shipbuilding on its head when it created the worldrsquos first commercial ship model experiment tank in . The football pitch-sized tank still works today, more than  years after it was built, and visitors can watch it in action in this Dumbarton museum. You can also get a sense of shipyard le by scraping down a wax ship model or testing designs in a small demonstration tank.. The Devilrsquos Porridge Museum, Dumfries and GallowayStanfield, Annan Road, Eastriggs, Dumfries and Galloway Adults pound., children and concessions pound.Open Monday-Saturday am-pm and Sunday am-pmwww.devilsporridge.org.ukDonrsquot let the name confuse you: this museum is neither about porridge nor the devil. The name references the cordite propellant mixture produced by the people of Gretna to provide ammunition during the First World War, a compound that was nicknamed ldquodevilrsquos porridge by Arthur Conan Doyle. The museum tells the story of those who worked in the factory, as well as giving an insight into le in a nuclear power station, with a new exhibit that gives a virtual reality -degree walkthrough of nearby Chapelcross Power Station.. Scottish Vintage Bus MuseumM Commerce Park, Lathalmond, near Dunfermline Adults pound, concessions poundOpen every Sunday .pm-pmwww.svbm.onlineYou donrsquot have to be a transport geek to enjoy this collection of more than  old buses, which were in operation throughout Scotland between the s and the s. Trying to spot all the buses you remember is a great way to lose an hour or two, with the vehicles kept in immaculate condition thanks to the enthusiastic staff. They can also give you a guided tour and,yoursquore lucky, a ride on one of the buses.. Surgeonsrsquo Hall Museum, EdinburghNicolson Street  Open every day am-pmAdults pound., concessions pound, under-s not advised to attendwww.museum.rcsed.ac.ukNot one to visityou have a weak stomach, Edinburghrsquos Surgeonsrsquo Hall Museum holds one of the largest pathology collections in the UK. Visitors can expect to see a rangeof historical surgical instruments,dental tools and equipment and, moststomach-churning of all, body parts stored in jars.. Glasgow Police MuseumFirst floor of  Bell Street, Merchant City, Glasgow  Open Tuesday am-.pm and Sunday pm-.pm , freewww.policemuseum.org.uk This hidden gem of a museum charts the history of Glasgowrsquos police force ndashthe first in Britain ndash from  to . It may be small but it offers plenty to interest visitors, including unorms, photographs and newspaper clippings that detail crimes that were committed and solved in the city.. Orkney Wireless Museum Junction Road, Kirkwall, OrkneyOpen Monday-Saturday .am-.pm and Sunday .pm-.pm Adults pound, children and concessions poundwww.orkneywirelessmuseum.org.ukThe sheer notion of a ldquowireless is one that is likely to warrant blank expressions from younger generations. But for those who remember the radio in its heyday of cultural and practical importance, this museum will conjure up plenty of fond memories and nostalgia.. Savings Banks Museum, RuthwellRuthwell, Dumfries, Dumfries and GallowayOpen Thursday-Saturday am-pm , freewww.savingsbankmuseumIt might not sound particularly thrilling but this museum tells the le story of the fascinating Henry Duncan, the founder of the savings bank, who was born near Dumfries in . Visitors can learn more about Duncan, and the origins of the bank, as well as admiring the collection of home savings boxes, coins and banknotes from around the world.. Montrose Air Station Heritage CentreWaldron Road, Broomfield, Montrose, Angus Open Saturdays am-pm and Sundays pm-pm Adults pound, concessions pound, children freewww.rafmontrose.org.ukThe first operational military airfield established in the UK, Montrose Air Station played an integral part in the RAFrsquos operations throughout the Second World War. It is staffed by volunteers who ensure that visitors get a sense of le during the war ndash with a s room full of memorabilia, an Anderson air raid shelter and even a room replicating a pilotrsquos bedroom from . There are plenty of planes, both real and replica, with visitors encouraged to interact with any exhibits that donrsquot explicitly say otherwise.Glasgow, Gateway to Scotland: The best Charles Rennie Mackintosh within  minutes. Scotlandrsquos Secret BunkerUnderground Nuclear Command Centre, Crown Buildings, Troywood, St Andrews. Adults pound., children pound.Open every day am-pmwww.secretbunkerHidden under an innocuous farmhouse in the middle of rolling Fe countryside, this museum certainly lives up to its secretive name. The , square feet of underground bunker was intended to host the government during the Cold War in the event of a nuclear catastrophe. The command control centre, dormitories and even chapel that are contained within it demonstrate just how readied the British government was for such a calamity ndash and how only a precious few would have been spared.. St Vigeans Sculptured Stones Museum Kirkstyle, St Vigeans, Arbroath, AngusOpen by appointment ndash phone   to arrangeAdults pound, children pound, concessions poundThe village of St Vigeans might have just one main street but that street plays host to a remarkable museum of Pictish carved stones ndash  of the imposing stones were found in the village, and visitors can try to decipher their meaning through a iety of audio and tactile displays.. The Writersrsquo Museum, EdinburghLady Stairrsquos House, Lady Stairrsquos Close, Lawnmarket, Edinburgh  Open every day am-pm, freeEasy to miss off Edinburghrsquos bustling Lawnmarket, the Writersrsquo Museum pays homage to the lives of three of Scotlandrsquos greatest literary figures: Robert Burns, Sir Walter Scott and Robert Louis Stevenson. Its collection includes manuscripts, portraits and personal items from each writer ndash as well as a plaster cast of the Bardrsquos skull.. Museum of Scottish Lighthouses, FraserburghKinnaird Head, Stevenson Road, Fraserburgh Open Wednesday-Sunday am-.pmAdults pound., children pound., concessions pound.www.lighthousemuseum.org.uk Kinnaird Head Lighthouse was the first built on mainland Scotland, so it seems a fitting place to host a museum dedicated to lighthouses. Visitors can learn about the engineers who built the lights, try on a keeperrsquos unorm and enjoy a guided tour of the lighthouse itself.. Scottish Fisheries Museum, AnstrutherHarbourhead, Anstruther, Fe Open Monday-Saturday am-.pm and Sunday pm-.pmAdults pound, concessions pound, children freewww.scotfishmuseum.orgChildren will love this hands-on museum about the history of the fishing industry, with ldquodo touch signs that encourage you to interact with the exhibits. It highlights the struggles that come with the job, with audio from a trawler skipper, a replica fishermanrsquos cottage and preserved boats that give you a feel for a le spent at sea.. Shetland Textile MuseumBod of Gremista, Gremista Industrial Estate, Lerwick, Shetland Open Tuesday-Saturday pm-pm , entry poundwww.shetlandtextilemuseumThe quality of Shetland wool isworld-renowned and this museum pays homage to knitwear, lace and taatit rugs that are native to the island. Visitors can admire the quality of craftmanship on display, with frequently changing exhibitions and demonstrations that showcase the importance of textiles to this community.. Inveraray Jail, Argyll Church Square, Inveraray, ArgyllOpen every day am-pmAdults pound., children pound., seniors pound.www.inverarayjailThis th-century jail was used to try, sentence and imprison criminals of the day ndash some as young as seven ndash before it was closed to make way for prisons in larger towns across Scotland. Visitors can view historic torture weapons, walk around the cramped cells of the old prison and enter the county courtroom, listening to extracts from trials held there. There is also a ldquomodern-day cell to give a sense of what prison le is like today.Days Out: The best  wintry walks in Scotland

title: advice for supporters ahead of scottish cup game at pittodrie
story: Police Scotland officers along with partners are preparing to welcome thousands of football fans to Aberdeen for the Scottish Cup Quarter Final this Sunday.Kick off for the Aberdeen and Rangers game is at .pm and so the City Centre, Pittodrie, Aberdeen Beach and Seaton areas will be busier than usual.Police ask that fans heading to the stadium plan their journeys in advance and allow themselves plenty of extra time to get to the stadium. Match Commander Superintendent Richard Craig is encouraging everyone planning to watch the game either at Pittodrie stadium, a licensed premises or in their home to enjoy the match but to behave responsibly. He said: “It is well-documented that drinking too much alcohol can lead you to become more vulnerable to becoming involved in crime either as a victim or perpetrator. I am urging supporters to behave responsibly and be aware thatyou’re drunk you won’t be allowed entry to the stadium and you’ll miss the match. “Anyone who does become involved in disorder or any act of violence will be dealt with robustly. “Additional officers will be on duty across the North East and within the stadium on Sunday and they will be supported by specialist resources. Our officers are extremely experienced in policing football matches and will be able to offer assistance should anyone need it.“Although the new AWPRis an option for travel we would still advise all football traffic coming from South of Aberdeen to use the traditional supporters’ route into the city .“We are here to ensure the safety and security of all supporters attending the game and minimise disruption to the local community. "I would remind supporters that those entering Pittodrie will be closely monitored for possession of alcohol or pyrotechnics of any kind. It is a condition of entry to the ground that fans allow themselves to be searched and those who refuse will be turned away by the club. “We will be implementing policing operations throughout the day, including spot checks on buses and coaches travelling to the game."Superintendent Craig added: “Pyrotechnics are extremely dangerous and endanger the safety of those around you as well as your own safety. We will take action, you will be arrested.“The match is undoubtedly a big event and we are looking forward to it. title: charities hold last entries to run garioch
story: The last few remaining places for Run Garioch are held by six local charities.This year’s Run Garioch charity partners are CLAN, Chest, Heart  Stroke Scotland, The Gathimba Edwards Foundation, Friends of the Neonatal Unit, Charlie House and Inspire PTL. There’s such a great spirit and atmosphere on the day and everyone thoroughly enjoys the experience.” She added: “As charities, we really cannot thank the organisers of Run Garioch and all the participants enough for their continued support."Race Director Graham Morrison added: “Run Garioch prides itself in being a community event that benefits so many groups and organisations. title: crossing borders with your dog after brexit
story: A. Pet passports list the dferent treatments your pet has had and ensures they are microchipped and up to date with their rabies vaccine.Read more: JD Wetherspoon favours more UK products as Brexit moves closerThe passport means your pooch wont have to go into quarantine on arrival.If the UK leaves without a deal, then the rules will change and pet passports issued in the UK would no longer be valid.In this case, pet owners would need to get a health certicate - and the bad news is, this will take at least four months. title: golden celebrations for couple
story: An Ellon couple have celebrated their golden wedding anniversary, marking  years together.Bill and Isobel Bonner reached the milestone on Friday, March .The couple first met at the Victoria Hall in Ellon, but Bill first dated Isobel’s sister before eventually asking his future we out.Isobel said: “My sister didn’t mind us being together, she ended up being one of my bridesmaids.”The pair were together for three years and engaged for two before marrying at Dyce Parish Church on March   when Isobel was  and Bill was .Bill originally hails from the Tarves area, and Isobel from Oldmeldrum, but the couple made the move to Ellon in January .Through the years Isobel worked at the Stoneywood paper mill before working at Ellon’s former Haldanes store on the checkouts for  years, a job that she really enjoyed.Meanwhile Bill spent time working on a local pig farm and he now works as a lollypop man for Meiklemill School, and is also a part-time janitor.The couple have two sons, Mark and Robbie, and two grandchildren, Ryan and Megan.Bill and Isobel will celebrate their anniversary with close friends and family at the weekend.Commenting on their achievement Isobel said: “It is amazing but the last  years or so have just flown past.“I am the only one in my family to have reached this anniversary.”Bill added that it felt “fantastic” to celebrate  years together.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.thesouthernreporter webimage ..! title: inverurie screwfix shop is approved

title: msp to host surgery for eu nationals amid brexit uncertainty
story: Aberdeenshire East MSP Gillian Martin will be holding a drop-in surgery for EU citizens concerned about the impact of Brexit on their settled status.It comes as the UK Government continues to negotiate its exit deal from the European Union before the expected leave date of March .Ms Martin has invited EU citizens living in her Aberdeenshire East constituency to join her at two separate events in Inverurie and Mintlaw this Saturday .Figures obtained from Spice, the Scottish Parliament’s research and information centre, show that there are around , EU nationals living and working in Aberdeen City and , in Aberdeenshire.People who want to stay in the UK must apply for settlement status through the EU Settlement Scheme.The first session will be held in Inverurie at the Garioch Community Education Centre from am till noon.The second session will be held in Mintlaw in the afternoon from pm till pm at the Macbi Centre.Commenting, Aberdeenshire East MSP Gillian Martin said: “I would encourage any EU citizens living in my constituency who have questions and are concerned about what applying for settled status means to them, to come along to the drop-in surgeries.“This is a very concerning time for everyone, not least for the huge number of EU nationals who have moved to Scotland and made our country their home.“The UK Government continues to cause uncertainty and there is a huge lack of reassurance available.“While many of the powers regarding EU citizens are reserved to Westminster, we will do all we can to help those living here in the North-East.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: new handbook aims to help local playgroups
story: The task of running a community based playgroup will be made easier for local groups with the publication of a free guide giving invaluable information and advice on managing their affairs smoothly.The guide, ‘Partnership for Success: a Committee Handbook’, has been prepared and published by Aberdeenshire Council and the charity Early Years Scotland, and will be launched at the Garioch Heritage Centre in Inverurie on Tuesday, March .The voluntary committees in charge of community playgroups can often feel overwhelmed by the demands and responsibilities of employing staff and keeping their group afloat, so the handbook is intended to help support them and enable a smooth handover for future committees.A copy of the handbook will be distributed to every playgroup in Aberdeenshire.Many of the playgroups are Early Learning and Childcarefunded providers for the local authority, and will have a vital role to play when the number of funded ELC hours parents can access for their child is doubled to , next year.The launch will bring together committee members and employees from local playgroups, alongside representatives from Aberdeenshire Council, Early Years Scotland, and local councillors.Speakers will include Jean Carwood-Edwards, Chief Executive, Early Years Scotland Laurence Findlay, Director of Education and Children’s Services, Aberdeenshire Council and Audrey Hendry, Lead Officer Education, Aberdeenshire Council.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Police Scotland"  Advice for supporters ahead of Scottish Cup game at Pittodrie viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: oldmeldrum publican loses 2am licencing bid
story: An Oldmeldrum publican believes others in the trade are #wasting their time# applying for a am drinks licence after a failed bid by his own premises.Robin Philip, owner of Morris’s Hotel, was unsuccessful in his application for an extra hour on a Friday and Saturday for his public bar in a bid to boost dwindling trade.Dficult trading times in an economic climate hampered by increases in business rates and operating costs had prompted his application to extend weekend drinking times.However Aberdeenshire Central Licensing Board stuck to its policies which limits pubs and hotels to a am licence but which offers nightclubs am licences Sunday to Thursday and am on Fridays and Saturdays.The board had earlier heard objections to the later opening element of the application from Sgt Kim Wood on behalf of Police Scotland who said there was clear evidence that the longer and later on-sales licensed premises operate, the “higher the likelihood of incidents of crime, disorder and anti-social behaviour occurring”.But the Oldmeldrum publican stressed he had not experienced trouble in the  years he has run his business.He said the public bar only held  patrons who merely wanted to enjoy a slightly longer night out on a Saturday.Mr Philip said the crime figures presented by the police were for Ellon and Inverurie and had no bearing on Oldmeldrum.A motion by Cllr Marion Ewenson to approve elements of the application, including an outdoor drinking area, with the exception of the am Friday and Saturday extension, was unanimously approved.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: Barn owl numbers recover
story: CAITHNESS is considered to have the most northerly population of barn owls in the world ndash and they have recovered well after severe winters took their toll on numbers eight or nine years ago, according to RSPB Scotland.Representatives of the nature conservation charity were saddened to discover recently that a fit and healthy barn owl had apparently been killed by a vehicle in the county, but on the whole the birds are said to be doing well.Barn owls originally evolved in warm, dry climates where food is in abundance all year round. It is therefore unsurprising that barn owls in the north of Scotland have a hard time during the winter months, with peak mortality rates being between December and March due to starvation.As temperatures start to drop in winter, small mammals become less active, meaning a lot less food is available for barn owls, and they need to work extra-hard to find it. This often results in the owls being forced to feed during daylight, even though they are naturally nocturnal hunters.This lack of food is particularly dangerous for barn owls as they are poorly insulated and need more food in winter to provide them with enough energy to stay warm.The Barn Owl Trust estimates that between  and  barn owls are killed each year on UK roads.RSPB Scotland site manager Dave Jones recently sent a deceased barn owl to the Scottish Agricultural College in Thurso for autopsy, when some concerned neighbours reported it after finding it at the roadside.The results of the autopsy showed that the bird was fit and healthy, "in good shape and hunting successfully", and that the death followed trauma to its wing and abdomen ndash suggesting that the bird died as a result of being hit by a vehicle.Dave said: "It is extremely sad to discover that a fit and healthy birds le ended in this way. The barn owls in Caithness really are at the edge of their natural comfort zone and are particularly vulnerable in winter, so it isnt an unusual result, unfortunately. Its not all doom and gloom, though. Although we still find some casualties in this way, our population of barn owls in Caithness has recovered from the particularly poor winters of   and  , and they are considered to be the most northerly population of barn owls in the world."While we cant control the weather, there are some things we can do to help. If putting up a nest box, please make sure it isnt placed close to any busy roads. If you see a road casualty and it is safe to do so, please stop and report the find to your local wildle officer and to the Barn Owl Trust. This is helpful in identying accident black spots and monitoring for environmental hazards and poisons, and potential wildle crime."Saturday  Mar  : AM

title: Delay to Wick 20 mph speed limit plans
story: THE brakes have been put on plans to introduce a  mph speed limit on the majority of roads in Wick.The proposal was mooted by Highland Council as a way to improve road safety and encourage walking and cycling.However, Wick members of the Caithness committee this week described the scheme as "a blunt instrument" and said other measures to reduce speed would be more effective. They also felt the consultation period should be extended by three weeks to allow the public more time to respond to the plan.Speaking at the meeting in Wick Town Hall on Wednesday, Councillor Nicola Sinclair said she was "very much in favour" of improving road safety but was concerned about the scale of the  mph limit and claimed there should be a longer period of consultation."The consultation took place over the Christmas period and I dont think people got enough opportunity to get their views heard," she said.Full report in Fridayrsquos John OrsquoGroat Journal.Saturday  Mar  : AM

title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Saturday  Mar  : AM

title: Roadworks to be carried out at four Caithness locations
story: ROAD improvements costing pound, are to be carried out at four Caithness locations, starting next week.The work, to be carried out by Bear Scotland, will begin at Hempriggs on the A on Monday and will conclude at Thrumster in April.A spokeswoman for the company said: "We have a pound, programme of road improvements planned across four locations in the Caithness area on the A and A in March and April."Starting on Monday, surfacing improvements will first take place on the A at Hempriggs for  days to address the worn-out road surface and localised rutted sections. Works will then move to the A south of Georgemas for  days from Monday, March , to carry out surfacing improvements on the route."A three-day patching project will then take place on the A Berriedale south brae which will address defects in the road surface, followed by an eight-day surfacing project for a stretch of the A at Thrumster in April."The spokeswoman said the projects will take place during the day, from am to pm, with no work planned at weekends to keep disruption to a minimum. A mph convoy system will be in place during working hours to escort traffic past the works areas at each location."Teams will do all they can to complete the projects as quickly and safely as possible. However, we encourage people to plan their journeys in advance by checking the Traffic Scotland website for up to date journey information," the spokeswoman added.Wick and east Caithness Highland councillor, Raymond Bremner, has been pressing for the road improvements on that section of the A and is "absolutely delighted" they are going ahead."The northbound side of the road has been in a deteriorating state of repair for some time and it certainly looked as though we were needing more than a pothole repair approach," he said. "I reviewed the road with an engineer in the spring of last year. As a result, and after a lot of discussion between the agencies, Bear and Transport Scotland, Irsquom delighted the remedial works are about to start."Saturday  Mar  : AM

title: Scottish Government urged to help secure future of Caithness Horizons
story: A CALL has been made for the Scottish Government to "play its part in securing a future for Caithness Horizons".It was made by local MP Jamie Stone in a letter to First Minister Nicola Sturgeon and comes after talks between representatives of the museum and gallery and Highland Council.Horizons chairman Craig Brown said: "The meeting was positive in discussing possible options for long-term financial stability to allow Caithness Horizons to reopen. Further meetings are scheduled over the coming weeks."Regarding widespread concern about the future of the museum collection, Mr Brown said it "remains complete and in the same safe condition while the next steps are discussed" with the local authority.Mr Stone, the MP for Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross, described Horizons ndash which closed unexpectedly last week ndash as part of "a string of pearls" to entice visitors to the area, the others being the Castle of Mey and Dunrobin Castle.He urged the First Minister to help identy a way "to keep this vital facility open".Mr Stone said: "I was appalled to hear of this closure ndash not least because it doesnrsquot seem that long since it was first opened. Caithness Horizons has been a great success in interpreting the geology, wildle and history of the far north for local people and visitors alike. It is up to date, visually striking, full of information and everyone who has been has come away much enthused."The closure of Caithness Horizons is precisely what we cannot allow to happen and it is for this reason that the Scottish Government should play its part in securing a future for the facility."Councillor Struan Mackie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, is concerned about public statements on dispersing the collection and says that is "contrary to the founding principles of Horizons".He said any part of the permanent collection not on loan "must remain in Caithness, regardless of the future of the Horizons facility. And in the event of closure the permanent collection would revert to the Highland Council."Councillor Mackie says the local authority should explore alternative operating models and wants "a cast iron commitment to ensure our countys heritage stays in Caithness for future generations."Ian Leith, chairman of the Wick Society, which runs Wick Heritage Museum in the townrsquos Bank Row, described the closure of Caithness Horizons as "a great loss"."From a heritage point of view it is certainly important, particularly its collection which should not be broken up and dispersed," he said.Mr Leith emphasised that the heritage groups in Caithness are not in competition "but telling parts of the same story". He said: Caithness Horizons had its part to play. Now its gone it is a great loss, but hopefully it can be retrieved."He said the Thurso museum and gallery had "very dedicated and very experienced staff".Mr Leith added: "It is too important to lose, particularly its heritage collection which has a national signicance. If it was broken up it would dilute the story. Whatever the future holds, the collection must be retained."Saturday  Mar  : AM

title: Slow progress on old church
story: A COUPLE who want to transform a derelict church in Castletown into their home say their plans are "progressing slowly".Angus Cowap and Dr Heather Davis purchased the th century church near the village primary school from Highland Council a year ago and have been "clearing a lot of rubbish" from the site but are now preparing for the next stage of the project.Mr Cowap said numerous consultations, studies and negotiations have been carried out and the proposals are beginning to take shape.The couple, who moved to the village three years ago, plan to replace the ruined roof and put some solar  on the south face of the building, re-glaze the windows and construct a double garage and a conservatory sun room."Internally, we will strip out the ruined fabric and make a simple open-plan living space," Mr Cowap said, stressing it will be a long-term project.He and Dr Davis moved north when she joined a medical practice in Thurso.They have spent some time clearing trees which were in danger of undermining the structure and have been shting rubbish, including rusty old cars and vehicle parts, from around the site.The church is believed to date back to  and was used by the RAF as a mess hall in World War II. It was later the site for residential caravans.Saturday  Mar  : AM

title: Urgent action needed after twins are born 52 miles apart
story: A CALL has been made for the Scottish Government to act on maternity provision in Caithness after a mother gave birth to twins at hospitals  miles apart.Local MP Jamie Stone described what happened as "a fiasco" and "shameful" and said it was time First Minister Nicola Sturgeon and her cabinet took action to deal with the situation.Highlands and Islands MSP Rhoda Grant raised the matter in the Scottish Parliament, while Caithness Health Action Teamsaid the case highlighted the maternity problems in the far north.Mr Stone, the Liberal Democrat MP for Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross, said: "No woman should have to face this when giving birth. It is shameful that it has taken a fiasco like this for the Scottish Government to sit up and take notice."Thankfully, the mother and both babies are healthy and we must thank the local NHS staff for their excellent work."However, this is a situation that neither the mother nor the staff should have been put in and we desperately need action from the Scottish Government."Geography and distance should not be something expectant mothers have to deal with and the government must accept that no-one should lack access to health services simply because of where they live."He spoke out after the womans ordeal was made public. She went to Caithness General Hospital in Wick in November after her waters broke when she was  weeks pregnant.It was decided she should go by ambulance to Raigmore in Inverness, over  miles away, to have her babies.But as she was near Golspie, her contractions became stronger and she was taken to the local community hospital, the Lawson Memorial, where she gave birth to a boy.A helicopter was then to take the woman to the Highland capital but was unable to land due to frost on its propellers so she made the rest of the journey by ambulance and gave birth to the second twin.Labours Rhoda Grant raised the case in parliament and claimed the air ambulance should have been called when the woman went into labour.She asked: "It begs the question why was the air ambulance or emergency retrieval team not tasked initially to airlt the mum from Caithness "Will the First Minister investigate this and will she make sure that the air ambulance treats situations like this as a priority "Nicola Sturgeon promised to investigate and asked Scotlands health secretary, Jeane Freeman, to look into it.Bill Fernie, the chairman of Chat, said the case highlighted the groups concerns about mothers having to travel to Inverness to give birth."Fortunately, we have not had a tragedy yet and hopefully we never will ndash but this underlines the fears we have had since the changes were made to the local maternity unit. There has been no risk assessment for the people who have to travel to Raigmore to have their babies."There has never been a problem with care at Caithness General or Raigmore, but mothers here should get the same kind of access to treatment as they get in the cities and we used to have here. Why in an emergency cant the experts be on call to come to Wick rather than the other way round "I hope this Scottish Government investigation comes up with some solutions to this whole problem."NHS Highland said an internal review will be carried out to consider the specic circumstances of this case.Saturday  Mar  : AM

title: Wick Francis Street Club placed in liquidation
story: WICKS Francis Street Club has been placed in liquidation, it was confirmed on Thursday.According to provisional liquidator Iain Fraser, a partner with FRP Advisory, the decision was made following a decline in membership, rising costs and unsustainable cash-flow problems. The club ndash founded in the s as a British Legion ndash has now closed and six staff have been made redundant.Mr Fraser said: "The Francis Street Club has been a landmark social, entertainment and sports venue in Caithness for nearly  years. Sadly, the club has been suffering severe financial problems and liquidation was the only option available to the committee."We are working closely with the relevant agencies, including the Redundancy Payments Office, to ensure the staff receive as much support as possible. We are now offering the assets of the business for sale, including the building, fixtures and fittings, and would urge interested parties to contact our Aberdeen office as soon as possible on   ."The Francis Street Club started was a long-established social, entertainment and sporting venue which attracted some well-known names through its doors, including former world snooker champion Stephen Hendry who staged an exhibition match there.It served as a social club and ran both football and darts teams, both well supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.The premises closed last month. At the time, a statement issued by the club said: "It was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , ."A note subsequently posted on the door read: "We have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course."Saturday  Mar  : AM

title: hial air traffic controllers vote to strike
story: Air traffic controllers across Highlands and Island Airports Limited , including those working at Kirkwall Airport, have voted to undertake industrial action, following the rejection by Scottish Ministers of a business case to resolve a dispute over pay.The ballot of the controllers by Union Prospect saw  per cent of controllers vote for strike action, with  per cent backing action short of a strike. The turnout was  per cent.Prospect has said it will consult representatives next week before confirming industrial action plans. The action is likely to start in April and continue through the summer.This situation arose after HIAL airport controllers sought a pay rise, as they said they were being paid half as much as their counterparts in other areas. However, HIAL said this isn#t the case and proposals were rejected by Scottish Ministers.Prospect negotiations officer David Avery said: “Our members at HIAL undertake highly skilled roles, much in demand across the UK and Europe, but due to public sector pay restraint their pay has fallen signicantly behind the rest of the industry.“Air Traffic Controllers do not want to have to take this action but ministers’ refusal to engage with the issue of pay has left them with no choice. Prospect remains ready to negotiate at any point to avoid this action but ministers must come back to the table with a new meaningful offer.”HIAL managing director Inglis Lyon, has responded to news of the ballot, saying: “We are disappointed Air Traffic Controlcolleagues have chosen to take industrial action that is likely to have a signicant impact on passengers and the communities we serve in the Highlands and Islands.#The Prospect union has sought a double-digit pay award. As a government sponsored agency, HIAL must follow the Scottish Government pay policy. We cannot implement pay awards more than that directed by government.#HIAL made a pay award offer to all staff which was accepted following an overall ballot of trade union members and paid to all staff at the end of September .  This was backdated to  April  and saw colleagues receive increases of up to three per cent in line with Scottish Government Pay Remit Guidelines.#Prospect ATC members rejected the pay settlement, but nonetheless received the increase.#We are open to holding further talks with Prospect on a recruitment and retention allowance for Air Traffic Control staff that would further bolster an attractive remuneration package that already includes excellent pension benefits and holiday entitlements.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. story: Her Majesty The Queen has approved the appointment of Elaine Grieve as Vice Lord-Lieutenant of Orkney with immediate effect.Ms Grieve takes over from Keith Johnson, who retired recently having reached the statutory retirement age. She is the first woman to fill this post since the Orkney Lieutenancy was established in .The -year-old, is a Masters graduate of Glasgow University, a former head teacher and an honorary sherf, and was previously an assistant chief executive of Orkney Islands Council.The new Vice Lord-Lieutenant will assist the Lord-Lieutenant, Bill Spence, during the last year of his Lieutenancy duties. Living in Firth, she has Rousay, Longhope and Kirkwall family connections, having attended Kirkwall Grammar School before teacher training in Aberdeen.Ms Grieve  has wide interests in music, the arts and the voluntary sector. She is presently involved with the Orkney Folk Festival, the Pier Arts Centre Trust, Orkney Housing Association and Voluntary Action Orkney — where she is vice chairwoman.“It’s an honour to have been considered for this role,# said the new Vice Lord-Lieutenant.#I have family connections with the Orkney Lieutenancy and it’s such a great privilege to have been appointed Vice Lord-Lieutenant. story: Plans are developing to mark the centenary of the scuttling of the German High Seas Fleet in Scapa Flow, with a call for descendants to become involved in the programme of events.The deliberate sinking of the vessels on  June  remains one of the greatest losses of shipping ever recorded in a single day.One hundred years later, commemorations will be held on Midsummer’s Day  to remember the  German lives lost as a result of the internment and scuttling of the fleet.A programme of community events held around the time of the anniversary will reveal the historical signicance of the scuttling and mark its impact and continued legacy in Orkney.The events in  were witnessed by a large group of school children from Stromness, who were on an outing in Scapa Flow aboard a local vessel, the Flying Kestrel.Antony Mottershead, arts officer with Orkney Islands Council, said: “We are working with partners in Germany to seewe are able to identy and contact any descendants of the  sailors who sadly lost their lives.#Closer to home, we would like to hear from descendants of the children who were aboard the Flying Kestrel or have a close family connection to the events that unfolded that day.”Antony can be contacted at antony.mottershead@orkney.gov.uk or on   extension .copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: work to restore cemeteries set to get underway
story: Work to reinstate headstones laid flat in Orkney’s cemeteries is due to get underway shortly.Work will begin in Stenness, with the initial focus being on headstones that are under one metre tall, and were put up after .These will be reinstated at no cost to the family, according to Orkney Islands Council.Harvey Johnston, convener of Orkney Islands Council, said: “We apologise again for the upset and distress that has been caused to local families, and hope that they are comforted that appropriate action is being taken to put this right.#As a caring organisation, responsive to public concern, we will restore kirkyards to the condition people would expect.#The move follows a public outcry at the state of the county#s cemeteries and accusations that the authority had not informed relatives of their intention to lay a headstone flat.The council later issued a full apology.Interim work will also be carried out across a iety of cemeteries in the coming weeks, to infill the holes left by the headstones that have been laid flat.Councillor Johnston added: “As we look to the future, local folk’s safety will remain an important concern for us, and we will be resuming our headstone inspections at an appropriate time.“Be assured, though, that we’re taking steps to make sure that our actions are proportionate to the risk posed, that we mark stones identied as being unsafe and highlight these to local community representatives, and that we give relatives the time they need to discuss with us any work they might wish to carry out themselves.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. story: Bus Users Scotland will be seeking public feedback on Orkney bus services at two events in the county, this week. title: Climate action call comes to Inverness streets
story: CLIMATE change activists from the Black Isle and Inverness have shown their solidarity for school pupils across the world after the youngsters held a lsquostrikersquo to flag up ecological concerns.New group Extinction Rebellion Highlands and Islands held a stall in Inverness High Streetlast Saturday, asking passers-by to sign a petition calling for urgent action by Highland Council to do its bit to tackle the threat, amid growing worries that the planetrsquos global warming is nearing an irreversible tipping point.Organised by Black Isle activist Anne Thomas, who is also involved with Transition Black Isle, the stall attracted  signatures in the space of  minutes.The youth strike, which included Highland participants, was sparked by Swedish teenager Greta Thunberg who spoke at the last major UN Climate Change summit saying adults were not doing enough and time was running out.ldquoLots of people had been impressed by the stand the kids had taken and were keen to show their support, said Ms Thomas. ldquoThey agreed that government at all levels is not doing enough to stop dangerous levels of global warming and climate change.ldquoScientists say we have less than  years to prevent warming going over . degrees, so we need to take drastic measures now. We could be on the brink of a mass extinction like the one which wiped out the dinosaurs.ldquoThe petition asked that the Highland Council... reverse inconsistent policies and work alongside the media to communicate with residents.The petition also called on the local authority to pass a climate emergency motion to make the region carbon neutral by .Fiona Cormie who has just taken on the role of co-ordinator of the group, said they hoped to add ldquosignicantly to its number of petition signatories in the coming weeks and present them to the council.Saturday  Mar  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Conon Bridge pupils injury sparks community discussion
story: AN accident at a Ross-shire school which left a child with a badly broken leg will be discussed by Conon Bridge Community Council.Max McPhee was five when a large stone fell from a boundary wall at Ben Wyvis Primary School in May , crushing his leg.After months of treatment the youngster, now seven, has been left with one leg cm shorter than the other. This week it emerged that the boy had won legal action against Highland Council.The local authority, whose former chief executive Steve Barron had to apologise to parents for a series of faults with the building after its completion, had denied liability throughout the civil action.But it backed down when the boyrsquos solicitor Digby Brown proved it knew of an earlier debris fall one year before Max was injured.Secretary of Conon Bridge Community Council John Bruce said the matter will be on their agenda at their meeting next Wednesday.At the time of Maxrsquos accident, the chairwoman of the community council, Fiona MacKintosh, said there had been a catalogue of repairs to the pound million school since it opened in  including the closure of the main games hall.After the settlement was announced Maxrsquos mum Louiseaccused the council of acting shamefully over her sonrsquos injury. She said: ldquoItrsquos shocking that Highland Council didnrsquot have the decency to hold their hands up and just help a little boy who was hurt by their own failings.A Highland Council spokeswoman said: ldquoIt is the councilrsquos policy not to comment on insurance claims.Saturday  Mar  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Dingwall story circle is first of many
story: A HIGHLAND councillor hopes that a new story circle which uses books to tackle prejudice and intolerance will be the first of many across Scotland ndash following its successful arrival in Dingwall.Heartstone, which has been based in Dingwall for the past  years and works to build understanding across cultures and nationalities, has enjoyed success where in the UK with exhibitions in the likes of London and Edinburgh.And they brought the message lsquohomersquo last week with a new story circle in Dingwall library, reading the fantasy tale The Heartstone Odyssey.The novel is aimed at nine to -year-olds and sees the fantasy aspects interwoven with deeper issues such as prejudice and intolerance.The story circle was opened by John West from High Le Highland along with Highland councillor Andrew Jarvie and Sita Kumari, the director of Heartstone.Cllr Jarvie said working on the project had been a privilege, adding: ldquoI really do hope that this is the start of many of these story circles and that we can work with the Scottish Government to give this home grown organisation the  it deserves across Scotland.The story circle was lead by Ms Kumari who took on the role of storyteller and dancer as she brought to le the heroine of the story, Chandra.Ms Kumari, said: ldquoThis book deals with the issues through the imagination, without lecturing or preaching, changing hearts and minds to see beyond stereotypes and prejudice and to recognise a common humanity.She was inspired to create the organisation when she was first told the story over  years ago.ldquoIt was first told to me as an oral story on a three-day train journey from Mumbai to Chennai in the rsquos from which everything has followed, she explained. ldquoIt was a le-changing experience leading to the formation of Heartstone.Carmen Garcia-Pagan, library supervisor at Dingwall Library, said the library were delighted to be involved in the launch: ldquoThe Heartstone Odyssey is a thought-provoking tale which tackles some powerful issues.Saturday  Mar  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Family remember happy and friendly teenager after tragic accident near Inverness
story: The family of a teenager killed in a road traffic collision at Dochgarroch has spoken about their "happy-go-lucky boy who was always happy and friendly".Policehave confirmed that the -year-old who died as a result of the two-vehicle collision at around .pm on Sunday night was Samuel Foster, of Lochend near Inverness.The family said: ldquoSamuel, our darling boy, was incredibly popular and had a huge circle of friends. He attended Millburn Academy before moving to Inverness College two years ago to study engineering."He also worked at the bakery at Marks and Spencer for two years and loved his motocross biking and cars.ldquoSamuel was a happy-go-lucky boy who was always happy and friendly.ldquoSamuel was the youngest of four siblings and words canrsquot express how much he will be missed by his parents Heather and Lenny, his brother David and twin sisters Samantha and Kirsty, his nephew Reuben and niece Georgie.ldquoWe would like to thank the incredible number of people who have sent us messages of sympathy ndash your kind words mean so much and are a reminder of just how popular and well-loved Samuel was."We hope he will always be remembered this way.Saturday  Mar  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Gairloch sitooterie volunteers are hailed for transforming area
story: VOLUNTEERS who helped transform a coastal swathe of gorse-dominated wasteland near the pier in Gairloch into a popular visitor attraction have been acknowledged for their efforts.Keep Scotland Beautulrsquos Itrsquos Your Neighbourhood scheme rates initiatives to improve the natural environment for everyone to enjoy.The ldquoSitooterie created along a stretch of road now offers visitors and locals alike access to benches with a pleasant outlook across the water.Thanks to the efforts of volunteers and donations from well-wishers and local businesses, the area is also largely wheelchair-accessible and also boasts a quirky boat feature which has been a hit with local children.The assessment says locals have taken the area to their hearts since the first bench was located there.Sitooterie coordinator David Carruthers said: ldquoThis is a terric tribute to the whole community who have so involved themselves in this project either with ideas, finance or especially practical involvement.ldquoThe assessment is an amazing recognition of the dedicated work done by so many supporters.Saturday  Mar  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Landmark anniversary for Ullapool arts hub
story: ONE of the countryrsquos smallest independent art schools is set to celebrate a major milestone by marking the st anniversary of its flagship course.Bridge House Art in Ullapool has been running its Portfolio Course since the late rsquos.In that time the school has built a growing reputation and has hosted students from as far afield as Lithuania, France, Switzerland, Spain and the USA.And on Sunday will celebrate the anniversary with its annual exhibition of portfolio course work ndash following an intensive four month training in the visual arts for  people from across the UK and mainland Europe.RESONANCE opens and will run daily from am to pm to March  at An Talla Solais Gallery, West Argyle Street, Ullapool and entry is free.It promises to be an eclectic mix of drawing, painting, printmaking, jewellery and illustration. Much of the work will be available for sale.Eleanor White, founder and principal tutor said: ldquoThe ethos behind all of our courses is to encourage everybody to learn to communicate visually and express a genuine response to the environment around us. I have been delighted with the way this yearrsquos students have responded to the challenge, this promises to be an excellent exhibition.Coming from a range of ages and backgrounds, the students have one thing in common ndash a shared desire to develop as artists. The -week course covers a range of disciplines including painting, printmaking, textiles and sculpture. Each inidual spends the second term developing a themed body of work and these will be on show at the exhibition.Kittie Jones, senior tutor and award-winning professional artist, said: ldquoI am always impressed by the dedication, hard work and motivation of the students on this course, many of them have moved up here to be part of the course and the results speak for themselves.Saturday  Mar  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Ross shire MP backs calls for new access to cash regulator
story: PEOPLE in Ross-shire communities which have witnessed a string of bank closures need to have protected access to cash.Thatrsquos the view of MP Jamie Stone who is backing calls by consumer group Which  for the government to appoint a regulator to protect such access.Mr Stone, MP for Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross, says the ldquoalarming rate of bank closures has seen an increasing number of people struggling to find direct access to cash through ATMs, and as a consequence, sometimes find it dficult to pay for essential goods and services.Which  says that despite the increased popularity of digital and card payments, which have proven vulnerable to IT failures, ldquohaving access to cash is still a necessity for more than  million people across the country.It says Scotland has seen  bank branches close since , making it one of the worst affected areas in the UK. It says these closures risk having an impact on businesses and communities alike.It notes that  cashpoints have closed in a year, the majority free-to-use machines. It wants to see a regulator with sole responsibility for the cash infrastructure to ensure consumers and businesses can continue accessing cash.Mr Stone said: ldquoThe combined closures of bank branches and free-to-use cashpoints across Scotland continues at an alarming rate leaving people in my constituency without access to the cash they rely on.He says he doesnrsquot want to see people ldquoleft behind by technology.Your view  Email newsdesk@spp-groupSaturday  Mar  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Shedders build on Dingwall success
story: A MENrsquoS shed group in Ross-shire hopes to build on its success as it enters its third year.Dingwall Menrsquos Shed, which has celebrated its second anniversary, boasts more than  signed up lsquosheddersrsquo who work on inidual projects and share their expertise with like-minded folk who are good with their hands.Reflecting on the last year and looking ahead, the grouprsquos Andy Foley said: ldquoThe next two years are going to be at least as busy as the last two,not even busier since, in addition to more of the same, we need to raise funds to enable us to erect our own, desperately-needed custom-built premises in Dingwall.ldquoWe anticipate that this will allow us to flourish further by increasing our membership and the range of activities that we can offer.A pound grant through Groundwork UK, which manages the Tesco Bags of Help scheme, paved the way for the purchase of power tools and air filtration equipment.The group also helped a local scout group install a new window for its hall to provide some much-needed natural light.Members have also had talks on menrsquos health issues and photography, a basic first aid training session and made goods for sale from recycled wood and old oak whisky casks.Theyrsquove also helped to smarten up parts of Dingwall, such as the pathway along the canal, and knocked up a couple of picnic tables for the MOO Food project in Muir of Ord.Some members have also raised money for charities.There were just  menrsquos sheds in the UK a few years ago. In , the UK Menrsquos Shed Association became a registered charity with a view to providing more formal support to the growing movement. Today there are over  menrsquos sheds open and an additional  or more in planning at any one time.That accounts for around , or more lsquosheddersrsquo benefiting from regular social interactions, new and improved skills, and regular, active participation in activities they enjoy.The rate of growth of menrsquos sheds is between six and nine a month.Saturday  Mar  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: scottish doctor s cruel guantanamo bay legacy
story: The legacy of a Scottish psychiatrist whose mind control experiments were covertly sponsored by the CIA and later used against political prisoners worldwide # including in Northern Ireland and Guantanamo Bay # will be explored in the world premiere of the documentary Eminent Monsters at the Glasgow Film Festival tomorrow.Dr Ewen Cameron, a world-renowned psychiatrist who evaluated Rudolph Hess at the Nuremberg Trials, carried out highly controversial experiments at the Allan Memorial Institute in Montreal, and later worked on later worked on MK ULTRA Subproject , the CIA’s mind-control and brainwashing project.: Two-year-old Scots girl who died ‘fobbed off’ numerous times before cancer diagnosedIn  it emerged that the CIA had been funding the mind-control brainwashing experiments at the institute as part of MK Ultra. Now the disturbing background to the work of Cameron – dubbed the Eminent Monster by patients – will be revealed by Scots director Stephen Bennett.Also attending the world premiere is Moazzam Begg who spent nearly three years as a prisoner in Guantanamo Bay where he underwent torture much of which was based on Cameron’s research.Bennett, from Glasgow, said Cameron, who was born in Bridge of Allan, Stirlingshire, and died in , carried out a host of experiments including sensory deprivation on patients without their consent.: SNP set to back creation of new currency for an independent Scotland“Cameron’s entire focus seemed to sht after the Nuremberg Trials. He had a secret wing in the hospital in Montreal where he carried out experiments. The aim was to break patients’ understanding of time and space. The legacy can be seen in the torture techniques employed in Northern Ireland and in Guantanamo Bay.”Mr Begg, , a British Pakistani, was imprisoned by the US who claimed he was a member of al-Queda before being released in  without charge. “At the time I was being tortured I assumed it had been done to others. I knew it was a process systematically designed to break people down,” he said.“I was subjected to sensory deprivation, with goggles, ear masks and shackled. I was stripped naked with dogs snarling at me and could hear the noise of women screaming nearby, guns clicking. There was also watching the abuse of other prisoners and not being able to do anything. “When Stephen Bennett talked to me about Ewen Cameron I found it very shocking. That somewhere thought to be as benign as Scotland could produce someone like that. I do find it genuinely shocking that such a legacy exits.”©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings
